LINCOLN, NEB-: E JOURNAL CO.,»PRI* 1901.
STATE JOURNAL CO.,»PRINTERS.

Officb of Secretary of State,
Lixoolx, Neb., November 30, 1900.
To His Ej-crUnui/, (loveruor WWmm A. Poynter:
!<ir — I have the honor to transmit herewith a report of this department for the two years ending November 30, 1900. The report as presented will be found to contain the business transactions of this office in the nature of information relating to fees derived from filing articles of incorporation, transcripts, certificates, and labels. Also the transactions of the printing board, of the brand committee, and general remarks in regard to the several boards of which I am a member ; also appropriations and expenditures, together with a list of the notaries public, corporations, bank certificates, municipal and school bonds.
The object has been a compilation of such information as will prove of interest to the general public and of value to the state.
All of which is respectfully submitted.
Secretary of State.
W. F. Porter,

BOARDS.
The secretary of state, by virtue of his office, is a member, of
the following boards:
Board of Public Lands and BuHdings Board of Transportation.
Board of Educational Lands and Funds. Printing Board.
Board of Purchase and Supplies. Board of Pharmacy.
Board of Canvassers.
Board to approve bank bonds designating bank as state de-
positories.
Board of Prison Inspectors.
Board of State Brand Commission.

12
KErORT OP THE
REMARKS.
A statement of all transactions of the Prison Board, of which I am a member, will be fully set forth by the warden's report to the governor and does not need a further extended report
The Board of Purchase and Supplies meet quarterly in the office of the Commissioner of Public Lands and Buildings to let contracts. This work has been so satisfactory that it has been generally conceded that quite a saving has been made for the benefit of the state.
The Board of Pharmacy has, under the law authorizing the same, five members, called the Board of Examiners, that are appointed by said Board of Pharmacy, the labors of which devolves upon said examiners. They setting forth and reporting at the annual meeting the transactions of said board.
The State Printing Board will have some items of interest in this report under a separate heading.
The Board of Canvassers have canvassed the vote for supreme judge and two regents of the University in the election of L8S6, and the judges of the district court; also in the election of 1!KM> they have canvassed the presidential electors and one judge for the ninth judicial district.
The board to approve bank bonds designating banks as state depositories have approved twenty-nine bonds in the last two
The Board of Educational Lands and Funds have had regular meetings, of which several have been quite important. The records of the doings of said board are kept in the rommissioner's office.
The Board of State Brand Commissioners was created by the legislature of 1899, and I was made one of the members of that commission. A statement of its doings will be made in another part of this report.
I have caused to be compiled the Session Laws of 1899 and delivered them to the county clerks, state library, members of the legislature, and individuals interested in the same. Have

13
SE* 'RETARD OF STATK.
received the House and Senate Journals, election laws, road laws, from the Printing Board and delivered the same to the county clerks, members of the legislature of 181W, to the state library and parties desiring them for personal use.
I have compiled the Soldiers' and Sailors' Roster ready for the printer, but on account of the fire of Jacob North & Co. they were delayed in carrying out their contract to print the same, and, upon advice, it was thought better not to print the same, as the statistics will be taken for a new one next April and it would place two compilations almost at the same time, which would be an unnecessary expense to the state.
Of the several boards of which I am a member the most important by far is the Board of Public Lands and Buildings, having supervision of the capitol grounds and all public buildings except those of an educational nature. This office being the office of record of this board, all minutes of meetings, contracts, reports, and checking of vouchers against contracts made by the Board of Purchase and Supplies have grown to such dimensions that it requires all of the time of one of the clerks of this office to perform the duties. The institutions under the control of this board I have visited, some of them two and three timea, and found the management in good hands. This board had an appropriation of $10,000 for the care and repair of the capitol grounds. They employed Mr. W. B. Hester superintendent of the work, and also employed stone masons to fecement the crevices in the building so that it might not cause decay by rain sifting through the same. They also painted the walls of the corridors, had a new roof put over the library, and had the roof generally repaired and painted; also had the stone walks repaired, quite a number of the rooms papered, glass put in wherever game was broken; the dome painted; plumbing wherever it was needed. All of this work nearly exhausted the sum appropriated and left the building in excellent shape and stopped decaj'.
Mr. J. E. Crane, who has given the board such efficient help in aiding them to draw up plans and specifications and in the inspection of boilers and steam plants and other work that was

14

the west end of the building, which are now being completed

tailed report of work of this nature.
The board has purchased the ground and buildings at the
Soldiers' and Sailors' Home at Milford and put the same in good
repair.

My labors in this office for the past two years have been very
pleasant to me, and I have been aided quite efficiently by the
full office force and I do not look back with any cause for regret.
There has been perfect harmony in the office and the best of
good wishes towards one another. All of the force, without an
order, have helped to bear the burdens of the office where they
have fallen heavily on one of their number by dividing the
labors. The personnel of the office as it now stands is:
O. C. Weesner Deputy
Theo. Mahn Bookkeeper
S. E. Starrett Recorder
Nellie Purcell Clerk
Gertrude O'Sullivan Stenographer
A. E. Sheldon Clerk Printing Board
I am sure that the records and the mode of keeping them, as
well as the general detail work of the office, have been mate-
rially improved over former years. I have done my plain duty
to the best of my ability, and feel that the state has been well
served.

NEBRASKA LIVE STOCK BRAND AND MARK COMMIS
SION.
This commission, authorized by House Roll No. 347, of the twenty-sixth session of the legislature, the same being chapter 51 of the Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1899, begs leave to report as follows:
The act above mentioned became operative July 1, 1899, at which time, pursuant to call of the secretary (W. F. Porter, Secretary of State), committee convened at the office of the secretary of state. The Committee aforesaid appointed by his excellency. Governor W. A. Poynter, is composed of the following named persons: S. P. Delatour, Lewellen, Neb.; M. J. Blewett, Harrison, Neb., J. H. Quigley, Valentine, Neb.; W. F. Porter, secretarv of state. Lincoln, Neb.

19
SECRETARY OP STATE.
J. H. Quigley was elected chairman of the commission. The commission has convened on the following dates and remained in session until all brands had been considered then on file: January 2, 1900, March 19, 1900, July 12, 1900, September 20, 1900, November 20, 1900, and will convene again December 31,
At this date, November 30, 1900, 3,036 brand applications have been filed," including 125 substitutes. The first application having been rejected, the committee authorized the filing of a substitute without further cost.
This law, in its main features, is generally approved by the stockmen of the state; however, there are a few changes advanced by leading stockmen and the Northwest Cattlemen's Association will be placed before the next legislature which convenes January, 1901.
STATE PRINTING.
Under the operation of the printing law of 1897 competition for state printing has been active and constant the past two years. Contracts have been let at low figures, notwithstanding, the general advance in prices. The contract with the State- Journal Company for printing and binding 1,000 copies of the Supreme Court Reports, which they formerly held at $1.85 per page, expired, and on reletting was again secured by the same firm at $1.22£ per page. Other contracts have been let at figures as low, or slightly below, those of the preceding bienniuia- There has never been a time in the history of the state when it has received so much value for the money paid for printing. The very keenness of competition for state printing has its disadvantage — one of them being by imperceptible shadings to cheapen the quality of paper and binding used in state work. To prevent this, and, in fact, to raise the quality of stock in state work, a new schedule of specification was drawn up last year, which has resulted in securing much better grade of material in blanks and blank books. In some other items of state printing, binding and paper, for example, of reports of state societies

20
r> cr» T-»-»- An iliKt ORT OF THE
*nd state officers, there should be a better quality of material used. These reports go in exchange to other state libraries all •over the Union, and even beyond the sea. and ought to be of 4frtst class book material. The policy of the printing board has been, however, to keep within the appropriations — as nearly as urgent necessity and the requirements of the statute would permit — and the reduced appropriations of the past two years has required an adherence to strictest economy.
The printing law contemplates that all contract printing shall be let quarterly after advertisement. Three years' experience has shown that not more than a dozen printing houses in the state care to bid for state work,— and that the regular bidders are limited to three printing houses in Lincoln, four in Omaha and one in Fremont. Occasionally an emergency has arisen requiring the printing of a job of contract magnitude without waiting for the regular quarterly jKniod of advertisement. In these cases typewritten specifications have been prepared and sent to each of the regular bidders at the last quarterly period, thereby complying with the spirit of the statute, though not its letter, and securing practically the same competition that is secured by advertisement.
In the early morning of September 16. 1899, fire destroyed the printing establishment of Jacob Sartfc & Co.. and with it the entire edition of 2,000 senate and 2,000 house journals of the legislature of 1899 nearly ready for delivery. The fire also destroyed the original copy for these books as prepared by the clerks of the respective houses and both galley and page proofs of the same. On consultation with Jacob North & Co.. the firm expressed its willingness to print and bind a new edition of the journals if allowed sufficient time and furnished new copy. Examination of the statute showed that no specific provision had been made for an emergency like the one at hand. Each house of the legislature designates who shall prepare the copy for the printed journal and provides for their pay by resolution. The printing act of 1897 provides that these clerks shall furnish the printing board with copy of everything ordered printed. All this had been complied with. The question was whether there was

SKCRETARY OF STATK.
21
any authority to prepare new copy to take the place of that
destroyed and how the same was to be paid for. The Printing
Hoard concluded to take the responsibility of acting without
statute authority and to advertise for bids for preparing, proof-
reading, and indexing the new copy, with notification to bidders
that they would receive their pay for the work in a deficiency
claim to be presented to the next legislature, with approval of
the Printing Board. As this whole procedure was outside the
statute the board inserted the advertisement three times in two
leading daily newspapers of the state and sent personal notice
besides to the clerks of the 1891) legislature — the most probable
bidders. Bids were opened Dec. 30, 1899, as follows:
•I. Q. Berkley, house journal, preparing copy, proofreading, and indexing |600 00
Alpha Morgan, and A. R. Keini, senate journal, as above, 900 00
K. H. Langford, house journal, as above 394 60
K. H. Langford, senate and house journal, as above. . . . 794 60
The board, by a vote of two to one, ordered the contract to
be let to Mr. Langford on his joint bid for both senate and house
journal. Meanwhile some of the unsuccessful bidders secured
an injunction from Judge Holmes, of the Lancaster county dis-
trict court, to restrain the board from letting the contract. On
the hearing the court held that when the Printing Board as-
sumed authority to act it most act under its statutory require-
ments, advertising in rhree dajily papers for five consecutive
days. Pursuant to this decision the board readvertised and on
January 2'2, 1900, opened new bids as follows:

By a vote of two to one the board ordered contracts to be made with John Wall for the house and Maggie Kroese for the senate journal. Under these contracts new copy was prepared and the journals printed, being delivered during October and November, 1900.
Tabular statements which follow show in detail the bidders and bids made at each letting of contracts the past two years, the amount paid for printing and binding the principal items of state work, the contracts let to each of the successful bidders, and a comparative statement of printing appropriations and expenditures for the past ten years. It will be observed that deficiencies of several thousand dollars have had to be provided" for at each biennial session of the legislature, due to failure to provide funds sufficient to do the printing required by law.
It is again recommended that the various appropriations for contract printing be placed under the authority of the State Printing Board, and that these appropriations be sufficient to meet the requirements of the state, as demonstrated by the experience of the past four years.
